description: I read this in early high school a lot, and have my sister's beat-up copy, which got lent around a ton. It's a paperback with a cat and a fish on it. Still my favorite of the Murakami books, which have not aged well. I also like After Dark, for more complicated reasons.
title: Kafka on the Shore

description: This is a copy a friend lent me and I never gave it back to them. Some stories are okay, others fizzle. Poor cover design.
title: The Elephant Vanishes

description: Read this one late, which is strange considering its placement in the Murakami bibliography. Read it at age 19, felt seen, then regretted the feeling. But it still holds a place in my heart, and displays my love for old, drooping bookstores.
title: Norwegian Wood

description: A well-formed novel, compared to most Murakami. Bought this copy for one dollar at a library book sale. Besides moving along okay, it didn't imprint too much in my memory. A good summary of other Murakami books.
title: The Wind-up Bird Chronicle

description: Based loosely on an Italian film I don't remember. I bought this because it was assigned for a class, and needless to say it didn't workshop well in the room of thirty undergraduates.
title: The Sputnik Sweetheart

description: Ben Marcus has a great chance to take himself less seriously. This book represents the hope which was then squandered. Close to my heart anyway. I recommend reading Calvino for more of the same.
title: The Age of Wire and String

description: Haven't read this. My mother bought it for me because she knows I find Gaiman comforting. I'll return to it when I live in a small house at the edge of a wood somewhere.
title: Norse Mythology

description: This is my sisters' copy again. I have sudden fond memories reading this book and getting excited about an image of American grime and seaminess that doesn't exist how we want. That, and the tasteful softcore pornographic writing, which my middle-school mind needed?
title: American Gods

description: Gift from a friend, who had four copies of the same book. Fun read, and view of a strong co-author friendship.
title: Good Omens

description: Haven't read this yet, besides the first few pages. Picked up at a library book sale. In theory this is my entry into middle-stage DeLillo: before he starts thinking so much about death.
title: The Names

description: One of the big recent nee poet novels. I have thoughts on why The New Yorker fawned over this thing, and how it means they all need some therapy. Otherwise very funnily written, good music in the text. Extremely modern masculine.
title: Leaving the Atocha Station

description: The second attempt from nee poet Lerner. Shtick about writing a book about writing a book. Metaphors about storms. Beautiful writing and funny critique of New York that the masochists at The New Yorker again ate up. Made me tired.
Quick Pynchon. People know this book. I still like passages.
title: The Crying of Lot 49

description: The Big DeLillo that people know. I own two copies, one from a bookstore that's dead now, and the other from a weird book depot in south Des Moines. Great at the sentence level, and one of the rare DeLillo which has good chapter-level cohesion too. Less a collage and more of a saga.
title: White Noise

description: Old family hardback copy. The cover seems to be stained with something? Strong memories of being read to from this book. Probably influence of my comfort around Gothic motifs.
title: The Graveyard Book

description: Ha. Read mostly on the bus to and from high school during junior year. Hardback bought on amazon.com to mimic the library copy I originally read. It is sad I don't have my original reading copy. I go back to it to quiet head noise. Weird book.
title: Infinite Jest

description: I read this when I want to feel like shit.
title: Girl with Curious Hair

description: Title story and "Good Old Neon" for when I want to get literarily fucked up.
title: Oblivion

description: Have never read. In theory one of his better ones. No strong desire to read.
title: Libra

description: I have never read this in order. Annotated three stories after death of a friend. I don't know how to feel about masculinity, is the long and short of it.
title: Brief Interviews with Hideous Men

description: This was a gift from my sister, and could use more humor. I like the story of how he was strong-armed into writing this thing.
title: Everything and More: A Compact History of Infinity

description: Strong influence on my young psyche, and permanently informs my fears and sexuality. Original childhood copy of the third in a series.
title: Scary Stories 3

description: Have been in 'the middle' of reading this for a year now. Good hardback from the Bookhouse in Minneapolis. I keep hearing about how people's husbands are reading this book, which must mean it has something to do with fears about masculinity. Also Bolaño was dying from colon cancer during, which says something, ref. DFW's Oblivion's "Good Old Neon."
Read once because it had sat there so long. Definitely peek at the process of Mr. Gaiman's becoming. Many Amazonian women, so read that as you will.
title: Neverwhere

description: These are real fun and you won't be hurt by reading them. Great little riffs. Copy found in the sole English used book store in Tokyo, along with a bunch of other pomo and post-struct works, meaning some wiry white man proverbially blew his literary load before leaving (fleeing?) the country. Great find. Bright orange cover.
title: Mythologies

description: Have never read, but found this copy practically for free. Friends have pressured me to like it.
title: The Master and Margarita

description: I can't read books about mathematics like this. But it is fun at the sentence level. Apparently DeLillo's favorite. Mommy issues?
title: Ratner's Star

description: These are good before sleeping. Sparse, tense.
title: Engine Empire: Poems

description: This is my other copy of White Noise. I don't dare conflate them.
title: White Noise

description: Great when you want to feel like crap.
title: Notes from Underground

description: Soaked in western media but in a fun and non-exhausting way that gives me real hope. Great springboard to others, even if I don't return to it all the time. Title story is really worth it, and bits and pieces break off into so much else I read, so it's sort of like coming home to an insensitive family member.
title: Lost in the Funhouse

description: I stole this from my sister and then never read it. Very pop.
title: The Man who Mistook His Wife for a Hat

description: Saw bits and pieces in the Lucas film on Mishima's life, but have never gotten into the work proper. Could use more homoerotic spattering.
title: The Temple of the Golden Pavilion

description: I haven't read this yet because I got disheartened by some Mishima after a brief infatuation with his more self-pick-axing stuff.
title: The Sailor Who Fell from Grace with the Sea

description: A copy I stole from a friend who said he'd never read it. I read it and then listened to a lot of people say what I should think about it. Generally found important and well-written.
title: Lolita

description: Picked up for free, and have been picking through it.
title: Despair

description: One of the better ones if you want a cozy storytelling set against some quality thought experiments. A thicker volume.
title: The Sandman: World's End

description: Flashier than some of them. Can't say it stuck with me though.
title: The Sandman: Brief Lives

description: Sign of Gaiman coming into his own with this comic series. Solid art.
title: The Sandman: Season of Mists

description: I ripped through these, and it's hard to say what happened in what. But this one, if I remember, had a weaker premise and a singular one, meaning less than impressive, comparatively.
title: The Sandman: Dream Country

description: The opening, with plenty of MPDG.
title: The Sandman: Preludes and Nocturnes

description: A ridiculous book.
title: Gravity's Rainbow

description: Read this at an important and isolated time, and it came through. Good format, didn't feel out of place, renewed my interest in movies, and made it with me on many a walk from place to place. Good read all around.
title: Kiss of the spider woman

description: Gift from my mother. Happy to read it once.
title: Dune

description: One of those Oxford copies. Fine poem. Bought for a class at a ridiculous price.
title: The Waste Land

description: Gift from my sister and encapsulates the kernel of white suburban sadness. Yates works hard at the sentence and even paragraph level. I understand why sad people quote him so much. Like reading a sigh.
title: Revolutionary Road

description: Never read save in sections. Hard to swallow.
title: The Sot-weed Factor

description: Read only in sections. Tough gig.
title: Giles Goat-boy, Or, The Revised New Syllabus

description: Men are weird.
title: Paradise

description: I enjoy Calvino's or Ishiguro's take on Arthurian legend, but this is what it is.
title: The King

description: Picked up for free and have only flipped through when I'm feeling needy for a high school era comfort tale.
title: Shadow Show

description: I stole this from my brother and read so that I could get people off my back for not having read Faulkner. Nice prose but could use more about death.
title: As I Lay Dying

description: Bought for a class, and I return to it when I need a little more mysticism in my life.
title: Selected Poems And Four Plays

description: This was from the pile of pomo and post-struct books left by someone in a Tokyo used bookstore. Fun read, but only if I'm very awake or very inebriated.
title: Writing and Difference

description: Big text: I've never read this all the way through.
title: Ulysses

description: My mother's old copy. I read an annotated this after the death of a friend.
title: The Catcher in the Rye

description: This is a gift from Rosemarie Ho. I promise you I'll read this slim volume.
title: Chronicle of a Death Foretold

description: I bought this for a class, but have developed an allergy to people who want to start their books referencing it. I want to read Ovid's facial-care manuals instead. But regardless they're fun stories.
title: The Metamorphoses of Ovid

description: I gave my dad a fresh copy of this for his birthday, and ruined my own copy with rainwater. Both were bad decisions. Of the old and melancholy DeLillo. Read "The Starveling" instead.
title: Point Omega

description: This was a gift from a friend before he went to Chile to find himself.
title: Beaches II

description: I bought this for a class. I say the word 'Fagles' to amuse myself.
title: The Odyssey

description: I mean, he wrote a good book.
title: The C Programming Language

description: I bought this for a class, and it is not the most detailed retelling, but is great for rainy day moods.
title: King Arthur and His Knights of the Round Table

description: I've picked through pieces of this. It does okay.
title: On Suicide

description: A strong translation, but a weak cover.
title: Sappho

description: I never read this. RIP.
title: Mort

description: This is a fine book, but I've got some wonky super tall and narrow copy that makes it tough to flip through on the beach, as it is designed for.
title: Small Gods

description: This is a strong, dry book on QM by the guy you want to be telling you about it. I've never gotten bad ideas from this book.
title: The Principles of Quantum Mechanics

description: I stole this from my sister. I promise I'll use it okay.
title: The Culture Industry

description: I bought this for a class but took real peace in reading it. This guy lived in a couple of ways that I respect.
title: An Attempt at Exhausting a Place in Paris

description: Strong but nothing to write home about.
title: Topics in Algebra

description: I bought this for free and never actually read it. Someday when I feel terrible I will.
title: Gargantua and Pantagruel

description: My mother bought this for me because I asked. Tell me you don't cry.
title: The Giving Tree

description: I got this for a great deal. I keep getting stuck in finishing it though.
title: N W

description: I bought this for a class and it makes me a little sad to read it because it strikes a mode I can never appreciate, relying too much on puns and the language of the bay area tech world. Like maybe I can appreciate it in its clunk.
title: The Absolute Letter

description: Written by a previous professor who has been nothing but good to me. Can't say I've read it all though. No verbs, only gerunds?
title: The Sampo

description: These are strong but not necessarily life changing poems. Tough bar, admittedly.
title: Disorientations

description: This book taught me during a pivotal year in mathematics, and my teacher let me take home this beat copy. I appreciate her help, without which I would have felt small and bad at what I did; i.e., little lies can go a long way.
title: Linear Algebra and Its Applications

description: I stole this from Dr. Dell's classroom and I am sorry for that. I will mail it to you someday about a decade from now.
title: An Introduction to Differentiable Manifolds and Riemannian Geometry

description: This book is a bad printing, but nevertheless will get you where you need to go. I think of it like a forklift.
title: Principles of Quantum Mechanics

description: I bought this on a whim and never read it because the movie is so prominent and I think that's allowed to be left the way it is. One of those mass-markets made because people in Carhart beanies want to read the original, or at least buy them.
title: A Clockwork Orange

description: I liked his short stories and then I bought this at a used bookstore in DC and promptly never read it because I fear he's not the writer I thought he was.
title: Everything Matters!

description: I won this along with a prize in the physics department. Makes me sad to look at.
title: Seven Brief Lessons on Physics

description: Nice cover, wandering book.
title: The Pillars of the Earth

description: My father bought me these because I kinda guilted him into it. They're overpriced but solid, well-bound, beautifully illustrated. I guess I have them now. I highlighted one chapter from the second volume and now I feel bad, but I also view it as a mark of my youthful vigor, or something.
title: The Feynman Lectures on Physics: Boxed Set

description: A platinum-blonde bowl-cutted Nietzsche-scholar from Hamburg taught me this book and I'll never forget it.
title: Capital Vol 1

description: One of his better known works, you know?
title: Leviathan

description: I stole this from a friend and we keep missing each other in order for me to return it to him. I'm sorry!
title: The Foucault Reader

description: Fanon is a strong writer that we spent pitifully little class time on.
title: The Wretched of the Earth

description: I mean, how /do/ I read him? I stole this from my apartment's communal bookshelf. For some reason I took it with me to Japan.
title: How to Read Derrida

description: Fun play, but better watched than read.
title: Endgame and Act Without Words

description: A gift from a friend that I flip open when I want to remember them.
title: Memory play

description: This wasn't worth the money or the time it took to read.
title: The Tragedy of Mr. Morn

description: I felt less certain after reading this.
title: On Certainty

description: All of this is solid, but I wish he spent more time talking about his daddy issues and degradation fetish.
title: The Major Political Writings of Jean-Jacques Rousseau

description: This is a prettily bound and effective kanji reference book.
title: 肝要漢字

description: This was a gift and arguably a fun read, but I've only ever jumped around in it.
title: "Surely You're Joking, Mr. Feynman"

description: This has good illustrations, but feels cheap.
title: The Audubon Society Field Guide to North American Mushrooms

description: I got this for free, and it's one of those books where the annotations make up eighty-percent of the bulk and it feels like reading the Torah.
title: The Annotated Flatland

description: I cut this book up for a collage but probably that's okay.
title: Tuva Or Bust!
いやでも物理が面白くなる

description: He's a smart guy but I am not a chemist and so most of this book is not helpful to me. Visionary stuff though.
title: Chemical Applications of Group Theory

description: This is a weird binding from a Scandinavian press, but is still a solid work and a pleasure to read; I love journal pieces that have good voice and economy.
title: Syntactic structures

description: A big book I paid too much for, but covers everything I want in the voice I expect, so there'll be no discarding of it any time soon.
title: The Logical Structure of Linguistic Theory

description: This is a fun and useful manual if you care about building this kind of stuff. A good memento from a halcyon quarter.
title: The Art of Electronics Student Manual

description: This is my father's book, and it's like getting an heirloom. Maybe someday I'll reach its monastic attitude.
title: COMMON LISP

description: I rarely open this book, but I appreciate the mathematics it tries so hardly to unravel.
title: Incompressible Aerodynamics

description: God bless their hearts for doing their best.
title: Fluid Flow

description: Change your reference materials, University of Chicago Physics Department: you're better than this! Otherwise sort of fun and retro with and air of the gin-soaked early physics era.
title: An Introduction to Mechanics

description: I mean, we're all caught up in this, aren't we?
title: The Oedipus Cycle

description: Real fun illustrations, saved for free from a box in the rain. Ripped apart for collage but also read earnestly.
title: Film: a Montage of Theories

description: He's old, and he doesn't care anymore. It's great. Great use of the colon, whatever that says.
title: Garbage

description: She understands the body as a wonky machine, and has the blood imagery to prove it. Good book, under-appreciated.
title: All the Garbage of the World, Unite!

description: I stole this from my apartment bookshelf: shoot me.
title: Complete Works

description: Honestly optimistic, and I got it for free during my CS department sojourn. Really helps pump you up. Great gold-accented and embossed cover with some flair from the early days of digital graphic design. Love the Panglossian feel. Really American.
title: Teach Yourself C Programming in 21 Days
